questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding corporobasal index of the sacrum? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum

 

  • Corporobasal index helps in determining the sex of the individual from the pelvis.
  • Corporobasal index = Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100 / breadth of the base of the sacrum.
  • In males, it is >42 and in females, it is <42.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corporobasal index is calculated using the breadth of the first sacral vertebra and the breadth of the base of the sacrum, which helps in determining the sex of the individual.

 

Other Indices for Anthropometric Measurements:

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

questions.text:
Which of the provided statements about the muscle depicted in the image are true? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

Marked muscle in the image given is Rhomboid Major and minor.

 

 

1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. Both the rhomboideus major and minor muscles play a role in scapular retraction. This means they help pull the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body, which is an action involved in retracting the scapula. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also contribute to scapular retraction.
     

2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. The Rhomboids retract the scapula superiorly and medially from the medial border of the scapula, this in turn assists in elevation of the scapula along with upper fibers of trapezius..
     

3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly:

 

  • True. When scapula is retracted and elevated along the medial border by rhomboids the glenoid cavity turns inferiorly (the socket of the shoulder joint).

     

Other Option:
 

4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly:

 

  • False. The primary action of the rhomboideus major and minor muscles is not to tilt the glenoid cavity superiorly. Their main functions involve scapular retraction and elevation, as discussed in statements 1 and 2. Tilted movement of the glenoid cavity superiorly is not a primary function associated with these muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rhomboid Major and Minor muscles are key players in scapular stabilization, involved in retraction, elevation, and downward rotation of the scapula, aligning the glenoid cavity in a position that supports optimal shoulder function.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

 

Explanation:

 

Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

 

Types of Gallstones:

 

  • Cholesterol Stones: These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • Pigment Stones: Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • Mixed Stones: These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.

 

Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.

 

Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

choices.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.
Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given
Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of acute onset fever, and pain in the right lumbar region. It is associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

 

Explanation:

 

The management of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy involves several key steps to ensure effective treatment and prevent complications:

 

  • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.
  • Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy.
  • Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (‚â•50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration.
  • Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. The correct management protocol dictates:

 

  • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours, not 72 hours.
  • Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days, not just 5 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics: Correct. Hospitalization, urine and blood cultures, and starting antibiotics are all appropriate steps in managing acute pyelonephritis.

 

Option B. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Correct. Switching to oral antibiotics is appropriate once the patient is afebrile.

 

Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given: Correct. Maintaining a urine output of > 50 mL/h and using intravenous crystalloids are standard practices to manage hydration and ensure adequate renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discharge from the hospital should be considered once the patient is afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics should be continued for 7 to 10 days in cases of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involves? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both

 

Bullet fingerprinting / Ballistic finger printing:

 

  • Investigators using ballistic fingerprinting analyze a fired bullet or casing for scratches under a microscope. The markings, which ‚Äî like fingerprints ‚Äî are unique to each weapon, are then compared with those found on bullets used in separate shootings.
  • It involves both primary and secondary markings.

 

A. Primary markings (Class characteristics) occurs because bullet is slightly larger than the barrel. The primary markings are determined by Class characteristics are determined by manufacturing specifications, design and dimensions. They are most useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved. Class characteristics in fired bullet identification would be:

 

i. Number, diameter and width of lands and grooves

ii. Depth of grooves

iii. Direction and degree of rifling twist

 

B. Secondary Markings (individual / accidental characteristics): These are formed due to Irregularities (imperfections) on the inner surface of barrel itself which are specific for that particular weapon. These irregularities are produced by sticking of particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and is known as metallic fouling. They also result accidentally during the manufacturing process, usually microscopic in nature and have random distribution. They are useful in identifying the specific gun which was fired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullet fingerprinting utilizes both primary and secondary markings to identify a bullet, making it a comprehensive approach to forensic analysis in firearm-related investigations.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

 

Explanation:


The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.

 

  • Complete Mole:
    • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
    • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
      • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
    • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • Partial Mole:
    • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.
    • Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.

 

Educational Objective:


The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Page no 225, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the breast condition shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mondor‚Äôs Disease

 

Mondor's disease is a rare condition characterized by superficial thrombophlebitis of the subcutaneous veins, typically in the breast or chest wall, but it can occur in other parts of the body as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget's disease: Paget's disease is an insitu lesion of nipple which presents with nipple destruction.

 

Option C. Zuska's disease: Zuska's disease, also known as chronic periductal mastitis is characterized by slit like nipple retraction after repeated inflammation of lactiferous ducts seen in smoker females.

 

Option D. Tietze syndrome: Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition that affects the cartilage of the ribs and sternum, causing pain and swelling in the affected area. The exact cause of Tietze syndrome is unknown, but it may be related to trauma, infection, or underlying autoimmune or inflammatory disorders. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, tenderness, and redness over the affected area. Treatment options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of Mondor's disease includes pain, tenderness, and redness over the affected area, along with a palpable cord-like structure that corresponds to the thrombosed vein.
  • The diagnosis of Mondor's disease is made by physical examination.
  • Treatment for Mondor's disease includes restriction of arm movements, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), warm compresses, and compression garments to alleviate pain and inflammation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist used in the management of ADPKD. By blocking the action of vasopressin at the V2 receptor, tolvaptan inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts, leading to increased free water clearance (aquaresis). This can result in symptoms like dry mouth and increased thirst due to increased urine output and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 receptor agonism: Tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, not an agonist. Its mechanism of action is to block the V2 receptor, thereby increasing water excretion.

 

Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels: Vasopressin usually acts on the V2 receptor to increase cAMP levels, which in turn promotes water reabsorption in the collecting duct. Since tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, it would be expected to decrease cAMP levels in the kidney, not increase them.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolality: Tolvaptan's action leads to increased water excretion without a significant change in solute excretion, resulting in a decrease in urine osmolality, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan causes increased free water clearance by blocking V2 receptors, leading to symptoms of dehydration such as dry mouth and increased thirst. This is a direct result of its mechanism as a V2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

choices.text: Decorticate rigidity involves flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs.
Decorticate rigidity involves complete relaxation of all muscles due to brainstem injury.
Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flaccid paralysis of all four limbs.
Decorticate rigidity is the result of increased inhibition from the basal ganglia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department following a severe head injury sustained in a fall. On examination, he is unresponsive, but his vital signs are stable, and imaging reveals a large intracranial hemorrhage involving the cerebral hemispheres. The neurological team notes that his condition is consistent with decorticate rigidity. Which statement accurately describes decorticate rigidity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Decorticate rigidity involves flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs.

 

Explanation:

 

Decorticate rigidity, often seen in patients with damage above the brainstem, such as cerebral hemisphere lesions, is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs at the elbows and extension of the lower limbs. This posturing results from the disruption of the corticospinal tract while sparing the brainstem pathways that facilitate flexor muscle activity in the arms and extensor muscle activity in the legs. Decorticate rigidity typically occurs due to intracranial hemorrhage, brain injury, tumors, or abscesses affecting the cerebral cortex or descending pathways, leading to loss of inhibitory control over the spinal reflexes that regulate posture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decorticate rigidity involves complete relaxation of all muscles due to brainstem injury.
This statement is incorrect as decorticate rigidity involves abnormal posturing with flexion and extension patterns, not muscle relaxation. Brainstem injury often leads to decerebrate rigidity rather than decorticate rigidity.

 

Option C. Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flaccid paralysis of all four limbs.
Flaccid paralysis indicates a complete loss of muscle tone, which is not seen in decorticate rigidity. Instead, decorticate rigidity involves specific abnormal flexor and extensor postures due to upper brain dysfunction.

 

Option D. Decorticate rigidity is the result of increased inhibition from the basal ganglia.
The basal ganglia are involved in movement control, but decorticate rigidity is specifically related to damage affecting the corticospinal tract and the loss of cortical inhibitory input, not an increase in inhibition from the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decorticate rigidity is a condition characterized by abnormal posturing with flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs due to damage above the brainstem, such as from intracranial hemorrhage or brain injury. This pattern results from the disruption of corticospinal tracts while preserving brainstem control of postural reflexes. Recognizing the specific postural patterns associated with decorticate and decerebrate rigidity is essential for localizing neurological damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

 

  • The structure that is most likely damaged to result in severe watery diarrhea resembling rice gruel stool is the Zona Occludens.
  • Zona Occludens, also known as Tight Junctions, are specialized intercellular junctions between epithelial cells that regulate the movement of substances across the intestinal wall. They are located at the apical end of the lateral membrane of adjacent epithelial cells and are responsible for maintaining the integrity and impermeability of the intestinal barrier.
  • Damage to the Zona Occludens can result in increased permeability of the intestinal barrier, leading to the leakage of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is often seen in infectious diarrhea caused by bacterial or viral pathogens that can damage the tight junctions, leading to increased intestinal permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gap Junction: Incorrect. Gap junctions are involved in cell-cell communication and the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells, but they are not directly involved in regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option C. Adherent Junction: Incorrect. Adherent junctions are involved in maintaining cell-cell adhesion but are not primarily responsible for regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Incorrect. Hemidesmosomes are involved in cell-matrix adhesion and do not play a role in the regulation of intestinal permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with cardiac edema and neuropathy. The deficiency of thiamine can manifest in two main forms:

 

  • Wet beriberi: This form of thiamine deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system. It is characterized by symptoms such as tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. This condition is commonly observed in populations with diets heavily based on polished rice, such as in refugee camps.
  • Dry beriberi: This form affects the nervous system and includes symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

 

Thiamine deficiency can also lead to complications such as lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults. The diagnosis can be established by assessing erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin deficiency is rare and can be observed in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs (which contain avidin that binds biotin) for several months. Symptoms include anorexia, vomiting, dry scaly dermatitis, glossitis, and hypercholesterolemia. It can also occur in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without biotin supplementation.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency in pyridoxine is associated with neonatal seizures and other symptoms such as dermatitis, glossitis, and depression, but not specifically with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency in riboflavin, known as ariboflavinosis, presents with photophobia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and cataracts, but not with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

choices.text: It is a dematiaceous fungus
Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or joints
Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.
